column1: Encinitas is a beach city in the North County area of San Diego County
column3: it is approximately 25 miles (40 km) north of San Diego
column4: between Solana Beach and Carlsbad
column5: and about 95 miles (153 km) south of Los Angeles. As of the 2010 census
column6: the city had a population of 59

column1: The first people to settle in Encinitas were the Kumeyaay. Gaspar de Portolá
column3: visited the area in 1769 during the Portolá expedition and met residents from the nearby Kumeyaay village of Jeyal or Heyal
column4: near the San Elijo Lagoon. Portolá named the valley Los Encinos for the oak forest along El Camino Real
column5: where there was also a village that was likely known as Hakutl in New Encinitas.After Mexican Independence
column6: land was granted to Andrés Ybarra in 1842 to build Rancho Las Encinitas in what is now Olivenhain and New Encinitas
column7: from which Encinitas got its namesake. Encinitas is a Spanish name meaning "little oaks".The town of Old Encinitas formed in 1881 by Jabez Pitcher.The city was incorporated by 69.3% of the voters in 1986 from the communities of historic Encinitas
column12: and Olivenhain. The communities retain their identities and distinctive flavors.

column1: Encinitas can be divided into five areas:
Old Encinitas: a small beachside area featuring a mix of businesses and housing styles. Sitting along Coast Highway 101 (Historic US 101)
column4: and the early 20th century La Paloma Theater are located here. Old Encinitas is divided from New Encinitas by a low coastal ridge.

column1: New Encinitas: a newer region which features a golf course
column3: and is composed of larger tract homes.

column1: Olivenhain: a semi-rural region in eastern Encinitas
column2: composed of mostly single family homes
column4: and several private equestrian facilities. Olivenhain connects to Rancho Santa Fe via Encinitas Boulevard.

column1: Leucadia: a coastal community of the city. Leucadia features tree-lined streets and boulevards. The community features art galleries
column4: along with single family homes. This also contains beaches such as Beacons and Grandview.

column2: which features streets named after British cities and classical composers
column4: and the San Elijo Campus of Mira Costa College.

column1: Encinitas lies on rugged coastal terrace. The city is bisected by a low-lying coastal ridge that separates New and Old Encinitas. In the north of the city
column2: the coast rises in elevation and the land is raised up in the form of many coastal bluffs. These cliffs are subject to collapsing on the narrow beach. The city is surrounded by Batiquitos Lagoon and San Elijo Lagoon to the north and south

column1: Encinitas is located at 33°2′40″N 117°16′18″W. According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 20.0 square miles (52 km2). 18.8 square miles (49 km2) of it is land and 1.2 square miles (3.1 km2) of it (5.89%) is water. The city's elevation ranges between sea level and 402 feet (123 m) above sea level.

Mediterranean climate. Average daily high temperature is 72 °F (22 °C). Temperatures below 40 °F (4 °C) and above 85 °F (29 °C) are rare. Average rainfall is about 10 inches (250 mm) per year. The wet season lasts during the winter and spring
column3: when temperatures are usually cool. Average daytime temperatures hit 65 °F in winter and spring
column4: when rain and marine layer (fog) are common (May Gray/June Gloom). Nighttime lows range from 45-55 °F. The dry season lasts from summer through fall
column5: with average daytime temperatures ranging from 75-85 °F
column6: and nighttime lows being from the upper 50s–60s°F. Ocean water temperatures average 60 °F in winter
column10: strong Pacific storms can bring heavy rain. During the winter of 2015–2016
column11: the area saw rounds of severe thunderstorms.

column1: Encinitas Ballet. Encinitas Ballet is a classical ballet studio in Encinitas. It was established in 2008 by Sayat Asatryan
column2: former principal dancer of the Kremlin Ballet Theatre
column4: former soloist of the Mariinsky Ballet II.

column1: April Street Fair: annual two-day street fair
column2: held every April in downtown Encinitas

column1: Deep Pit BBQ: held the end of May at the San Dieguito Heritage Museum
Encinitas Environment Day: held on the 2nd Sunday of June- environmentally-themed games and entertainment for families.
Lima Bean Faire and Battle of the Beans Cook-off
column2: held each September at the San Dieguito Heritage Museum

column1: Fall Festival: annual one-day street fair
column2: held each November in downtown Encinitas.

column1: OktoberFest: held on the last Sunday in September to coincide with the Oktoberfest celebrations in Germany.
Classic Car Cruise Nights: classic cars line Coast Highway 101 in downtown Encinitas on the 3rd Thursday of each month

The Wavecrest Woodie Meet: takes place once a year on the third Saturday of September at Moonlight State Beach. It is the largest rally of wooden-bodied vehicles in the world and it is free to the public and to participants.
Wellness Week: annual week-long program of events and special offers designed to help people learn about and experience ways to improve their well-being.

Salute to Education: Encinitas Chamber of Commerce Salute to Education event that is held each year in June honoring local teachers and students for their outstanding efforts during the current school year. This event is hosted each year by Rancho Santa Fe Security Systems.
Switchfoot Bro-Am: annual free surf competition and outdoor music festival usually held in early July at Moonlight State Beach
column2: home of the world's only Surf Jousting competition
column3: along with several other competitive surfing events.  All proceeds from the event go to local charities.

column1: In 2011 Mark Patterson and Robert Nichols illegally installed a 10 by 10 feet (3 m × 3 m) mosaic of a surfing Virgin de Guadalupe on the north concrete support wall of the train bridge on Encinitas Boulevard
column2: leading to a battle over whether it should be removed or preserved. It was named "the Surfing Madonna" by the media and public.

column1: === Museums and other points of interest ===

column8: and one of California's classic downtown areas along historic Coast Highway 101. Surfing is a popular activity in Encinitas
column10: which is rated in the top 5 surf locations in the world
column11: and is mentioned in a verse of The Beach Boys' song "Surfin' U.S.A." A bronze statue "Humanity" was installed at J Street Overview in 2018. Sculptress is Maidy Morhous. Donors are Sue & Jay Vicory. Manchester Reserve is great for nature walk and light hiking.

column2: or more affectionately known by Encinitas locals as the Cardiff Kook
column3: is a 16 ft bronze statue located in Cardiff-by-the-Sea
column4: in the city of Encinitas. The San Diego Architectural Foundation
column5: in its annual "Orchids & Onions" awards for the best and worst architecture of the year
column6: awarded the Kook an Onion in 2007. The nickname comes from a derogatory surfer slang term for a "wannabe" surfer
column7: as surfers in the area realized that the statue's form whilst "surfing" was far from correct. However
column8: the Kook has become a local favorite in the city and has many wonderful traditions associated with it. At various times during the year
column9: the Kook is "vandalized" and dressed up (wearing a lucha libre mask
column10: being eaten by a paper-mache shark
column11: wearing a full Uncle Sam costume for Independence Day
column12: used by local high school students to ask each other to school dances) bringing local flair and tourists constantly to the statue.

column4: shops

column1: Coaster trains stop at Encinitas station multiple times a day
column2: 7 days a week with service from Oceanside to San Diego. Between 2013 and 2017
column3: Amtrak's Pacific Surfliner also stopped here
column4: but discontinued this stop due to low ridership.

column1: The city is currently governed by a five-member city council
column2: with a mayor and four council members.  The mayor is elected citywide and the council members are elected by district to staggered four-year terms at two-year intervals.  The deputy mayor is chosen by the city council members from among themselves.
Encinitas voted yes on ballot measures to allow them to directly elect its mayor
column3: with term lengths of two years
column4: rather than the mayor being chosen by members of the city council
column5: for one year terms. The first such direct election for mayor took place in 2014.

column1: The city has been repeatedly sued over policies which are allegedly aimed at undermining state affordable housing laws.
